results.title: Aussie assault
results.creator_credit: Harvey Spencer, Bill Scholer, Garry Holt and Sportmaster Programs
results.brief_description: A behind-the-scenes look at the work and preparation that went into Australia II winning entry in the America’s Cup. Shows the crew at leisure as well as at work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harvey Spencer, Bill Scholer, Garry Holt and Sportmaster Programs

results.title: Hawkins' rivers
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, TAS Television Productions and Eyelevel Production
results.brief_description: Leo McKern narrates this modern day adventure set in twentieth century Tasmania. The true story concerns Tasmanian doctor and canoeist John Hawkins, who led the fight to save the Franklin River. It was, and still is a dilemma between developing the natural resources of the land or to forgo development at the price of suffering potential economic, political and social consequences. It is an issue that commanded the rest of the nation’s attention and continues to be pertinent today.

results.title: Chris Pine disassociating
results.description: Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling? The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also seemed to represent an existential threat to cinema in the streaming age of IP-driven blockbusters, which many hoped ‘the movie’ would defy.
description_for_label: Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling. The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also somehow came off like an existential threat to cinema. Ironic, since many expected ‘the movie’ to be a hit that defied streaming and IP-driven blockbusters.

results.title: run 5: the journal of Strategic Studies Group [games magazine] Issue 25, 1996
results.creator_credit: Strategic Studies Group and Stephen Hand
results.brief_description:
Strategic Studies Group, commonly known as SSG, was an Australian software development company that primarily made strategy wargames. “Run5” was launched by SSG in January 1986.

Ian Trout had determined that print was the cheapest and most effective way to share new scenarios with the audiences for their games. In the editorial to the first edition Trout explains that print was much cheaper than creating disks which would “cost around $15 a pop”. As the son of a newspaper publishers and himself a bookshop proprietor Trout had a fondness for print publication and was interested in what SSG could achieve with its own magazine.

SSG was founded by strategy game enthusiasts Ian Trout and Roger Keating. Ian was proprietor of a military books store and Roger had had several of his games published by Strategic Simulations Inc. The game that launched the company was Reach for the Stars (1983). This games is credited for having “effectively launched the genre of 4-X space games - explore, expand, exploit, exterminate”. Its success was followed by a string of other, mostly historical military games published throughout the 1980s for Apple II, Atari, Commodore 64, and IBM PC series of computers. (some information for this entry dericed from Wikipedia)

description_for_label:
Strategic Studies Group, commonly known as SSG, was an Australian software development company that primarily made strategy wargames. “Run5” was launched by SSG in January 1986.

Ian Trout had determined that print was the cheapest and most effective way to share new scenarios with the audiences for their games. In the editorial to the first edition Trout explains that print was much cheaper than creating disks which would “cost around $15 a pop”. As the son of a newspaper publishers and himself a bookshop proprietor Trout had a fondness for print publication and was interested in what SSG could achieve with its own magazine.

SSG was founded by strategy game enthusiasts Ian Trout and Roger Keating. Ian was proprietor of a military books store and Roger had had several of his games published by Strategic Simulations Inc. The game that launched the company was Reach for the Stars (1983). This games is credited for having “effectively launched the genre of 4-X space games - explore, expand, exploit, exterminate”. Its success was followed by a string of other, mostly historical military games published throughout the 1980s for Apple II, Atari, Commodore 64, and IBM PC series of computers. (some information for this entry dericed from Wikipedia)
